thread.title: Caulfield Cup 2015: Sydney’s star spring stayer Magic Hurricane left riding his luck for a start in Caulfield feature
thread.title_full: Caulfield Cup 2015: Sydney’s star spring stayer Magic Hurricane left riding his luck for a start in Caulfield feature | DailyTelegraph

author: Nic Ashman
title: Caulfield Cup 2015: Sydney’s star spring stayer Magic Hurricane left riding his luck for a start in Caulfield feature
text:
SYDNEY’S top stayer of the spring, Magic Hurricane, has been delivered a Caulfield Cup snub, instigating a debate that jurisdictions need to work together to ensure the right horses line up in the country’s most prestigious races.
And Racing NSW boss Peter V’landys says he’s prepared to work in the spirit of cooperation with Racing Victoria to ensure the best horses line up in major races in the two states.
Magic Hurricane, the winner of The Metropolitan at Randwick last Saturday week, was left as fourth emergency meaning the Godolphin import needs three scratchings to gain a start in Saturday’s $3 million feature.
The Metropolitan has provided two Caulfield Cup winners in the past 10 years – Tawqeet (2006) and Railings (2007) – while champion galloper Saintly finished third in the race before taking out the Cox Plate-Melbourne Cup double in 1996.
Before his Metropolitan triumph, Magic Hurricane finished second to Preferment in Group 2 Hill Stakes.
Preferment has since captured the Group 1 Turnbull Stakes (2000m) at Flemington and been installed second favourite for the Melbourne Cup.
 V’landys believes the best races Australia-wide should be considered as qualifying races in the future, no matter what state they are run in.
“It’s their race and it’s their decision how to fill the field and I understand and respect that,” he said. “But as a country we should be supporting staying races and this is the perfect opportunity to show that support.
Who will win the Caulfield Cup? “The Metropolitan has proven a strong race for many years and we’d support the notion of making the winner exempt from ballot in the Caulfield Cup.”
And in good faith V’landys says he will sit down with Racing Victoria officials and nominate a list of races south of the border that guarantee a start in NSW’s premier events.
“The racing public wants to see the best horses in the best races and at a national level that’s what we should be trying to provide,” he said.
Magic Hurricane was allotted 50kg when weights were first released and copped a 2.5kg penalty for his Metrop win, one of the biggest weight penalties seen in more than 20 years.
But it still wasn’t enough to get a start. The problem is The Metropolitan is not a ballot exempt race for the Caulfield Cup but a race like the Group 3 Naturalism Stakes, held at Caulfield, is.
The winner of that race this year was Magnapal, who was subsequently beaten by Escado in the JRA Plate. Escado has since finished seven lengths behind Amralah in the Herbert Power Stakes.
Lloyd Williams elected not to run Amralah in Saturday’s $3 million race but if he had then Sydney Cup winner Grand Marshal would have missed a start. That would have meant the last two Group 1 winners over 2400m or more to come out of Sydney would not be lining up in the Caulfield Cup.
Racing NSW chief executive Peter V’landys. $3m CAULFIELD CUP
Saturday, Caulfield

19e. QUEST FOR MORE (IRE) R Charlton G Schofield (8) 53.5kg
